case_name: Appellant v. Union of India and Director General, Posts and Telegraphs, New Delhi

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated October 6, 1960, of the Punjab High Court Circuit Bench Delhi in L.P.A. No. 23-D of 1957.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated October 6, 1960, of the Punjab High Court  Circuit Bench  Delhi in L.P. A. No. 23-D of 1957.

facts.text: The appellant was appointed in June 1943 as an Engineering Supervisor by the second respondent.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was appointed in June 1943 as an Engineering Supervisor by the second respondent.

facts.text: In January 1949, he was suspended from service on account of certain activities of his which were considered to be objectionable.

anchor.surface_text: In January 1,949, he was suspended from service on account of certain activities of his which were companysidered to be objectionable.

facts.text: He was duly served with a notice to show cause, and his case was in due course considered by the Committee of Advisers, who recommended that he be retained in service.

anchor.surface_text: He was duly served with a numberice to cause, and his case was in due companyrse companysidered by the Committee of Advisers, who recommended that he be retained in service.

facts.text: The appellant was reinstated with effect from May 26, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: In pursuance of the recommendation of the Advisory Committee, the appellant was reinstated with effect from May 26, 1951.

facts.text: After passing his departmental examination in 1952, the appellant was appointed as officiating Sub-Divisional Officer, Telegraphs.

anchor.surface_text: After passing his departmental examination in 1952, the appellant was appointed as officiating Sub-Divisional Officer, Telegraphs.

facts.text: While he was so employed at Nagpur, he was served with a notice dated November 3, 1952, from the office of the Director-General, Posts and Telegraphs, under the provisions of rr. 3 and 4 of Civil Services Safeguarding of National Security Rules, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: While he was so employed at Nagpur, he was served with a numberice dated November 3, 1952, from the office of the Director-General, Posts and Telegraphs, under the provisions of rr. 3 and 4 of Civil Services  Safeguarding of National Security  Rules, 1949-

facts.text: The notice alleged that after reinstatement on May 26, 1951, the appellant continued to associate with others engaged in subversive activities raising doubts about his reliability.

anchor.surface_text: Whereas in the opinion of the Competent Authority as defined in rule 2 of the Civil Services  Safeguarding of National Security  Rules, 1949.  who in your case is the Director General  there are reasonable grounds for believing that after your reinstatement in service on May 26, 1951 you have companytinued to associate with others engaged in subversive activities

facts.text: Allegations: Soon after your arrival in Nagpur important local communists were reported to have contacted you and during the discussions you were reported to have interested yourself in the political activities of the Communist party and other political organisations and groups in Nagpur.

anchor.surface_text: The following are the allegations against you-- Soon after your arrival in Nagpur important local companymunists were reported to have companytacted you and I during the discussions you were reported to have interested yourself in the political activities of the Communist party and other political organisations and groups in Nagpur.

facts.text: You are also reported to be actively continuing your association with Shri N. Mukherjee and other prominent local Communists.

anchor.surface_text: You are also reported to be actively,continuing your association with Shri N. Mukherjee and other prominent local Communists.

facts.text: On November 17, 1952, the appellant submitted his answer to the show-cause notice denying the charge.

anchor.surface_text: On November 17, 1952, the appellant submitted his answer to the show-cause numberice.

facts.text: The appellant requested a personal hearing before the second respondent and the Committee of Advisers.

anchor.surface_text: The answer runs into 9 pages typescript to the effect that the charge was value. baseless and without foundation, and requesting for a personal hearing before the second respondent, as well as before the Committee of Advisers.

facts.text: On January 23, 1953, the appellant submitted a letter requesting that all evidence be made available at the oral hearing.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant submitted a letter on January 23, 1953, requesting that at the time of the oral hearing all the evidence on which the charges mentioned in your letter No. STA 98-10/52 dated 3.11.1952 have been framed, may be made available to him

facts.text: On January 28, 1953, the second respondent examined the appellant in person.

anchor.surface_text: On January 28, 1953, the second respondent examined the appellant in person,

facts.text: On May 19, 1953, he was served a second show-cause notice.

anchor.surface_text: and thereafter on May 19, 1953, he was served a second show-cause numberice,

facts.text: The Committee of Advisers considered the defence and record of personal hearing and provisionally opined sufficient grounds for compulsory retirement.

anchor.surface_text: The Committee of Advisers have companysidered the defence submitted by Shri V. S. Menon and the record of the personal hearing and are provisionally of the opinion that sufficient grounds exist to bring home these charges to Shri Menon, justifying his companypulsory retirement

facts.text: Shri Menon submitted his representation on June 18, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: Shri Menon submitted his representation on June 18, 1953.

facts.text: On August 28, 1953, order passed for compulsory retirement of Shri V. S. Menon.

anchor.surface_text: On August 28, 1953, the following order was passed against him Memorandum No. ST- A. 98-10/52/SEA Dated New Delhi, the 28th Aug. 53.

Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated October 6, 1960, of the Punjab High Court Circuit Bench Delhi in L.P.A. No. 23-D of 1957.

The appellant moved the erstwhile High Court of Judicature at Nagpur under Art. 226 of the Constitution. The case was heard by a Full Bench of three judges consisting of Kaushalendra Rao, V. R. Sen and Bhutt, JJ.

concepts.interpretation: Court under Art. 226 can grant declaration that service not legally terminated where procedure under security rules invalid.

anchor.surface_text: As the petition under Art. 226 of the Constitution in the Nagpur High Court proved infructuous, the appellant moved the Circuit Bench of the Punjab High Court at Delhi under the same Article.

While he was so employed at Nagpur, he was served with a notice dated November 3, 1952, from the office of the Director-General, Posts and Telegraphs, under the provisions of rr. 3 and 4 of Civil Services Safeguarding of National Security Rules, 1949.

concepts.interpretation: Strictly construed; applies only if servant (a) engaged in subversive activities, (b) reasonably suspected of being so engaged, or (c) associated with others therein in manner raising reliability doubts; plus prejudicial to security.

holdings.text: The charge against the appellant does not strictly come within the purview of r. 3 of the Civil Services (Safeguarding of National Security) Rules, 1949, as it only alleges association with others engaged in subversive activities without alleging engagement, reasonable suspicion thereof, or association raising doubts about reliability.

anchor.surface_text: It is manifest on the charge,, as framed against appellant that he was number even alleged to have been engaged or to be reasonably suspected to have been engaged in subversive activities or to be engaged in such activities in association with others. It was only alleged against him that he associated with others who were engaged in subversive activities.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Charge text compared to r.3 terms: lacks allegation of personal engagement, suspicion, or doubt-raising association; rule penal hence strictly construed.

holdings.text: Rule 3 of the Civil Services (Safeguarding of National Security) Rules, 1949, being of a penal character, must be very strictly construed.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Penal rules require strict construction to ensure precise fit; charge fails textual match.

holdings.text: As the charge did not come within r. 3, there was no basis for the procedure adopted under r. 4 of the Rules.

anchor.surface_text: As-the charge against the appellant did number strictly companye within the purview of r. 3, there was numberbasis for the procedure adopted in pursuance of r. 4.

holdings.reasoning_summary: r.4 procedure contingent on r.3 applicability; since r.3 inapplicable, no need to examine r.4 compliance.

holdings.text: Premature termination of the appellant's service before superannuation age, not justified under r. 3 and without equivalent to r. 148 Railway Establishment Code, is tantamount to removal from service by way of penalty attracting Article 311 protections.

anchor.surface_text: In the instant case, therefore, the premature termination of service before the age of superannuation companyld be justified only by virtue of r. 3. As r. 3 had number been attracted to the appellants case for reasons given above, it follows at the premature termination of the appellants service would be tantamount to removal from service by way of penalty.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No simple discharge provision like r.148; absent r.3, termination penal; distinguishes Balakotaiah precedent.

holdings.text: The appellant has a just grievance remediable under Article 226 and is entitled to a declaration that his service was not legally terminated in accordance with r. 3 of the Security Rules.

anchor.surface_text: In that view of the matter, the appellant certainly had a grievance which he companyld ventilate under Art. 226 of the Constitution, and on the findings arrived at by us on the main question he is entitled to the declaration that his service was number legally terminated in accordance with r. 3 of the Security Rules.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Invalid termination under security rules creates enforceable right; High Court jurisdiction under Art.226 for declaration.

holdings.text: The present case is distinguishable from Balakotaiah v. Union of India as there is no provision in Posts and Telegraphs Rules corresponding to r. 148 of the Railway Establishment Code allowing simple termination.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Balakotaiah relied on r.148 equivalence for non-penal nature; absent here, termination penal.

precedents.citation: Balakotaiah v. The Union of India 1

anchor.surface_text: Balakotaiah v. The Union of India  1 . That wascase in which the services of the appellants who were, railway servants had been terminated for reasons of national security under r. 3 of the Railway Service  Safeguarding of National Security  Rules, 1949.

precedents.cited_proposition: Rule 3 of the Railway Services (Safeguarding of National Security) Rules, 1949 is constitutionally valid, not repugnant to Art. 14, termination under it does not attract Art. 311 as it is not dismissal or removal by way of punishment, and stands on same footing as discharge under r. 148 Railway Establishment Code
precedents.cited_holding: the charge drawn up against the railway servants concerned showed not only that they were communists or trade unionists but that they were engaged in subversive activities

anchor.surface_text: Balakotaiahs case  1 governed the present case also. This Court held further that the charge drawn up against the railway servants concerned showed number only that they were companymunists or trade unionists but that they were engaged in subversive activities.

precedents.cited_proposition: the decision in the case did not govern the present case as charge here does not fall within r. 3

anchor.surface_text: 1  1958 S.C.R. 1052. that was number a case of dismissal or removal from service by way of punishment. It was also held in that case that the order terminating the services under r. 3 of the Security Rules stood on the same footing as an order of discharge under r. 148 of the Railway Establishment Code and was, therefore, outside the purview of Art. 311 of the Constitution.

precedents.cited_proposition: termination under r. 3 not a case of dismissal or removal attracting Art. 311(2), similar to discharge under r. 148
